Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Advanced Mixed Integer Programming Formulations

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is to improve the effectiveness of Mixed Integer Programming (MIP) by developing and using a new paradigm for constructing linear and nonlinear MIP formulations. Such formulations are used to describe the selection among a finite number of alternatives in optimization models and their attributes can significantly affect the performance of the software employed to solve these models. Unfortunately, there is often a strong trade-off between favorable formulation attributes. The research in this award will result on methods to systematically reduce these trade-offs. The approach to develop these methods will include a mathematical analysis of the proposed paradigm, the design of algorithms to construct the associated MIP formulations and extensive computational experiments to evaluate their effectiveness. The deliverables of this work include new mathematical techniques for constructing and analyzing MIP formulations, algorithms and software for using and evaluating advanced MIP formulations, and educational material for engineering students and practitioners.

If successful, the results of this research will provide tools to improve the effectiveness of optimization software for a wide range of MIP applications in business, science and engineering. Recent examples of such applications include efficient energy production and dispatch, clinical trial design and analysis, and trajectory optimization of unmanned aerial vehicles. Results from this research will be disseminated through various channels to allow their integration into commercial optimization software. In addition, all developed techniques will be implemented in open-source software tools available through a variety of modeling languages. The educational material developed in this award will help students at all levels develop crucial mathematical modeling skills. Graduate and undergraduate students will further benefit from this award through lectures and research experience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to improve the effectiveness of mixed-integer programming (MIP) by developing and using new paradigms for constructing linear and non-linear MIP formulations. Linear and non-linear MIP formulation attributes such as size and strength can significantly affect the performance of state-of-the-art MIP solvers. For this reason, linear MIP formulation techniques have been steadily developed in the last 50 years. While significant progress has been made, it is still common to have a trade-off between favorable formulation characteristics. For instance, it is rare to find strong and small formulations. Similar trade-offs exist in the context of non-linear MIP formulations.

The final outcomes of this project can be classified into three groups: (1) advanced techniques for constructing MIP formulations, (2) extended formulations in polyhedral approximation algorithms for mixed-integer convex optimization, and (3) mixed-integer convex representability. In the first group of results we developed geometric and combinatorial paradigms for constructing highly effective MIP formulations. Through a non-traditional use of binary and general integer variables, these paradigms can generate formulations that bypass standard trade-offs between favorable formulation characteristics. The resulting formulations can yield significant computational improvements for optimization problems using piecewise linear functions and applications in VLSI design. In the second group of results we adapted and used extended formulations to improve the performance of algorithms for mixed-integer convex optimization. The techniques we developed for the sub-class of mixed-integer conic quadratic optimization problems have already been adopted by state-of-the-art commercial and open-source solvers, and we have implemented the techniques for more general mixed-integer conic optimization problems in the open-source solver Pajarito. Lastly, in the third group of results, we considered the question mixed-integer convex representability: what can be modeled or represented using mixed-integer convex formulations? This question has proven significantly more technical than the classical results for (rational) mixed-integer linear formulations, but we were able to achieve notable advances. For instance, we developed a complete characterization for the class of 0-1 mixed-integer convex formulations and developed some necessary conditions for general mixed-integer convex formulations. The later result allowed us to show that the set of prime numbers (which can be modeled with mixed-integer non-convex polynomial formulations), is not mixed-integer convex representable. 

The outcomes of this project have led to significant improvements to various techniques for mixed-integer programming. Many of these improvements have already been incorporated into popular commercial and open-source software tools, which has allowed and will continue to allow them to have a broad impact in various applications in business, science and engineering. In addition, besides the mentioned applications on VLSI design, we are currently working on applying the techniques developed in this project to the problem of verifying robustness of a trained deep neural network to adversarial attacks. Finally, the work in this project has been incorporated into tutorials, courses and other educational material, and the successful training of three PhD students has been partially supported by this grant.
